sn35.107:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the origin and disappearance of the world.

sn35.107:1.3.eng: And what, mendicants, is the origin of the world?

sn35.107:1.4.pli: Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn35.107:1.4.eng: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn35.107:1.5.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn35.107:1.6.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

sn35.107:1.7.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping.

sn35.107:1.8.eng: Grasping is a requirement for continued existence.

sn35.107:1.9.eng: Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.

sn35.107:1.10.eng: Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.

sn35.107:1.11.eng: This is the origin of the world. …

sn35.107:1.12.pli: jivhañca paṭicca rase ca uppajjati jivhāviññāṇaṃ …pe…

sn35.107:1.13.pli: manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn35.107:1.13.eng: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn35.107:1.14.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn35.107:1.15.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

sn35.107:1.16.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping.

sn35.107:1.17.eng: Grasping is a requirement for continued existence.

sn35.107:1.18.eng: Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.

sn35.107:1.19.eng: Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.

sn35.107:1.20.eng: This is the origin of the world.

sn35.107:2.1.eng: And what is the ending of the world?

sn35.107:2.2.pli: Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn35.107:2.2.eng: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn35.107:2.3.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn35.107:2.4.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

sn35.107:2.5.eng: When that craving fades away and ceases with nothing left over, grasping ceases.

sn35.107:2.6.eng: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.

sn35.107:2.7.eng: When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.

sn35.107:2.8.eng: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.

sn35.107:2.9.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn35.107:2.10.eng: This is the ending of the world. …

sn35.107:2.12.pli: manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn35.107:2.12.eng: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn35.107:2.13.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn35.107:2.14.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

sn35.107:2.15.eng: When that craving fades away and ceases with nothing left over, grasping ceases.

sn35.107:2.17.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn35.107:2.18.eng: This is the ending of the world.”

sn35.108:1.1.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati kiṃ upādāya kiṃ abhinivissa seyyohamasmīti vā hoti, sadisohamasmīti vā hoti, hīnohamasmīti vā hotī”ti?
sn35.108:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, do people think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’?”

sn35.108:2.1.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn35.108:3.1.pli: “Cakkhusmiṃ kho, bhikkhave, sati cakkhuṃ upādāya cakkhuṃ abhinivissa seyyohamasmīti vā hoti, sadisohamasmīti vā hoti, hīnohamasmīti vā hoti …pe…
sn35.108:3.1.eng: “When there’s an eye, because of grasping the eye and insisting on the eye, people think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’. …

sn35.108:3.3.pli: manasmiṃ sati manaṃ upādāya manaṃ abhinivissa seyyohamasmīti vā hoti, sadisohamasmīti vā hoti, hīnohamasmīti vā hoti.
sn35.108:3.3.eng: When there’s a mind, because of grasping the mind and insisting on the mind, people think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’.

sn35.108:3.5.eng: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”

sn35.108:5.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.108:5.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn35.108:7.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya seyyohamasmīti vā assa, sadisohamasmīti vā assa, hīnohamasmīti vā assā”ti?
sn35.108:7.1.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would people think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’?”

sn35.108:12.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.108:12.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn35.108:14.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya seyyohamasmīti vā assa, sadisohamasmīti vā assa, hīnohamasmīti vā assā”ti?
sn35.108:14.1.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would people think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’?”

sn35.108:16.1.pli: “Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmimpi nibbindati …pe… manasmimpi nibbindati.
sn35.108:16.1.eng: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

sn35.108:16.2.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn35.108:16.2.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn35.108:16.3.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn35.108:16.3.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn35.109:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the things that tighten the fetters, and the fetter.
sn35.109:1.1.comm: This disourse and the next parallel SN 22.120–21.

sn35.109:1.3.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, saṃyojaniyā dhammā, katamañca saṃyojanaṃ?
sn35.109:1.3.eng: What are the things that tighten the fetters? And what is the fetter?

sn35.109:1.4.eng: The eye is something that tightens the fetters.

sn35.109:1.5.pli: Yo tattha chandarāgo, taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ …pe…
sn35.109:1.5.eng: The desire and greed for it is the fetter.

sn35.109:1.7.eng: mind is something that tightens the fetters.

sn35.109:1.8.pli: Yo tattha chandarāgo, taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ.
sn35.109:1.8.eng: The desire and greed for it is the fetter.

sn35.109:1.9.pli: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, saṃyojaniyā dhammā, idaṃ saṃyojanan”ti.
sn35.109:1.9.eng: These are called the things that tighten the fetters, and this is the fetter.”

sn35.11:0.3.eng: The Exterior as Suffering in the Three Times

sn35.11:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, sights of the past and future are suffering,

sn35.11:1.3.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako atītesu rūpesu anapekkho hoti;

sn35.11:1.4.pli: anāgate rūpe nābhinandati; paccuppannānaṃ rūpānaṃ nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hotī”ti …pe….

sn35.110:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the things that fuel grasping, and the grasping.

sn35.110:1.3.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, upādāniyā dhammā, katamañca upādānaṃ?
sn35.110:1.3.eng: What are the things that fuel grasping? And what is the grasping?

sn35.110:1.4.eng: The eye is something that fuels grasping.

sn35.110:1.5.pli: Yo tattha chandarāgo, taṃ tattha upādānaṃ …pe…
sn35.110:1.5.eng: The desire and greed for it is the grasping.

sn35.110:1.7.eng: mind is something that fuels grasping.

sn35.110:1.8.pli: Yo tattha chandarāgo, taṃ tattha upādānaṃ.
sn35.110:1.8.eng: The desire and greed for it is the grasping.

sn35.110:1.9.pli: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, upādāniyā dhammā, idaṃ upādānan”ti.
sn35.110:1.9.eng: These are called the things that fuel grasping, and this is the grasping.”

sn35.111:1.1.pli: “Cakkhuṃ, bhikkhave, anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.111:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, without directly knowing and completely understanding the eye, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering.
sn35.111:1.1.comm: This is similar to SN 35.26, as is the next discourse.

sn35.111:1.2.eng: Without directly knowing and completely understanding the ear …

sn35.111:1.6.pli: manaṃ anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.111:1.6.eng: mind, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering.

sn35.111:1.7.pli: Cakkhuñca kho, bhikkhave, abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāya …pe…
sn35.111:1.7.eng: By directly knowing and completely understanding the eye, having dispassion for it and giving it up, you can end suffering.

sn35.111:1.8.eng: By directly knowing and completely understanding the ear … nose … tongue …

sn35.111:1.10.pli: manaṃ abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāyā”ti.
sn35.111:1.10.eng: mind, having dispassion for it and giving it up, you can end suffering.”

sn35.112:1.1.pli: “Rūpe, bhikkhave, anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.112:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, without directly knowing and completely understanding sights …

sn35.112:1.6.pli: dhamme anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.112:1.6.eng: ideas, without dispassion for them and giving them up, you can’t end suffering.

sn35.112:1.7.pli: Rūpe ca kho, bhikkhave, abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.112:1.7.eng: By directly knowing and completely understanding sights …

sn35.112:1.12.pli: dhamme abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāyā”ti.
sn35.112:1.12.eng: ideas, having dispassion for them and giving them up, you can end suffering.”

sn35.113:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā nātike viharati giñjakāvasathe.
sn35.113:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying at Ñātika in the brick house.
sn35.113:1.1.comm: This is the same as SN 12.45; see there for notes.

sn35.113:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā rahogato paṭisallīno imaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ abhāsi:
sn35.113:1.2.eng: Then while the Buddha was in private retreat he spoke this exposition of the teaching:

sn35.113:1.3.pli: “cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn35.113:1.3.eng: “Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn35.113:1.4.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn35.113:1.5.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

sn35.113:1.6.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping.

sn35.113:1.7.eng: Grasping is a requirement for continued existence.

sn35.113:1.8.eng: Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.

sn35.113:1.9.eng: Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.

sn35.113:1.10.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn35.113:1.12.pli: manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn35.113:1.12.eng: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn35.113:1.13.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn35.113:1.14.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

sn35.113:1.15.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping.

sn35.113:1.16.eng: Grasping is a requirement for continued existence.

sn35.113:1.17.eng: Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.

sn35.113:1.18.eng: Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.

sn35.113:1.19.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn35.113:2.1.pli: Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn35.113:2.1.eng: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn35.113:2.2.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn35.113:2.3.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

sn35.113:2.4.eng: When that craving fades away and ceases with nothing left over, grasping ceases.

sn35.113:2.5.eng: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.

sn35.113:2.6.eng: When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.

sn35.113:2.7.eng: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.

sn35.113:2.8.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn35.113:2.10.pli: manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn35.113:2.10.eng: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn35.113:2.11.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn35.113:2.12.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

sn35.113:2.13.eng: When that craving fades away and ceases with nothing left over, grasping ceases.

sn35.113:2.15.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”

sn35.113:3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu bhagavato upassuti ṭhito hoti.
sn35.113:3.1.eng: Now at that time a certain monk was standing listening in on the Buddha.

sn35.113:3.2.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā taṃ bhikkhuṃ upassuti ṭhitaṃ.

sn35.113:3.4.eng: “Monk, did you hear that exposition of the teaching?”

sn35.113:3.9.eng: That exposition of the teaching is beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life.”

sn35.114:0.2.eng: 12. The World and the Kinds of Sensual Stimulation

sn35.114:1.1.pli: “Santi, bhikkhave, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.114:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.114:1.2.pli: Tañce bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati—
sn35.114:1.2.eng: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them,

sn35.114:1.3.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āvāsagato mārassa, mārassa vasaṃ gato, paṭimukkassa mārapāso.
sn35.114:1.3.eng: they’re called a mendicant trapped in Māra’s lair, fallen under Māra’s sway, and caught in Māra’s snare.

sn35.114:1.4.eng: They’re bound by Māra’s bonds, and the Wicked One can do with them what he wants.

sn35.114:2.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, jivhāviññeyyā rasā, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.114:2.1.eng: There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.114:2.2.pli: Tañce bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati—

sn35.114:2.3.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āvāsagato mārassa, mārassa vasaṃ gato, paṭimukkassa mārapāso. Baddho so mārabandhanena …pe….

sn35.114:3.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, manoviññeyyā dhammā, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.114:3.1.eng: There are ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.114:3.2.pli: Tañce bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati—
sn35.114:3.2.eng: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,

sn35.114:3.3.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āvāsagato mārassa, mārassa vasaṃ gato, paṭimukkassa mārapāso.
sn35.114:3.3.eng: they’re called a mendicant trapped in Māra’s lair, fallen under Māra’s sway, and caught in Māra’s snare.

sn35.114:3.4.eng: They’re bound by Māra, and the Wicked One can do with them what he wants.

sn35.114:4.1.pli: Santi ca kho, bhikkhave, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.114:4.1.eng: There are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.114:4.2.pli: Tañce bhikkhu nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati—
sn35.114:4.2.eng: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them,

sn35.114:4.3.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu nāvāsagato mārassa, na mārassa vasaṃ gato, ummukkassa mārapāso.
sn35.114:4.3.eng: they’re called a mendicant not trapped in Māra’s lair, not fallen under Māra’s sway, and released from Māra’s snare.

sn35.114:4.4.pli: Mutto so mārabandhanena na yathākāmakaraṇīyo pāpimato …pe….
sn35.114:4.4.eng: They’re free from Māra’s bonds, and the Wicked One cannot do with them what he wants.

sn35.114:5.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, jivhāviññeyyā rasā, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.114:5.1.eng: There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.114:5.2.pli: Tañce bhikkhu nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati—

sn35.114:5.3.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu nāvāsagato mārassa, na mārassa vasaṃ gato, ummukkassa mārapāso. Mutto so mārabandhanena na yathākāmakaraṇīyo pāpimato …pe….

sn35.114:6.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, manoviññeyyā dhammā, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.114:6.1.eng: There are ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.114:6.2.pli: Tañce bhikkhu nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati—
sn35.114:6.2.eng: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them,

sn35.114:6.3.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu nāvāsagato mārassa, na mārassa vasaṃ gato, ummukkassa mārapāso.
sn35.114:6.3.eng: they’re called a mendicant not trapped in Māra’s lair, not fallen under Māra’s sway, and released from Māra’s snare.

sn35.114:6.4.pli: Mutto so mārabandhanena na yathākāmakaraṇīyo pāpimato”ti.
sn35.114:6.4.eng: They’re free from Māra’s bonds, and the Wicked One cannot do with them what he wants.”

sn35.115:0.2.eng: 12. The World and the Kinds of Sensual Stimulation

sn35.115:1.1.pli: “Santi, bhikkhave, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.115:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.115:1.2.pli: Tañce bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati—
sn35.115:1.2.eng: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them,

sn35.115:1.3.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu baddho cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu, āvāsagato mārassa, mārassa vasaṃ gato, paṭimukkassa mārapāso.
sn35.115:1.3.eng: they’re called a mendicant who is bound in sights known by the eye. They’re trapped in Māra’s lair, fallen under Māra’s sway, and caught in Māra’s snare.

sn35.115:1.4.eng: They’re bound by Māra’s bonds, and the Wicked One can do with them what he wants.

sn35.115:2.1.eng: There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.115:2.2.pli: santi, bhikkhave, manoviññeyyā dhammā, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.115:2.2.eng: ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.115:2.3.pli: Tañce bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati—
sn35.115:2.3.eng: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them,

sn35.115:2.4.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu baddho manoviññeyyesu dhammesu, āvāsagato mārassa, mārassa vasaṃ gato, paṭimukkassa mārapāso.
sn35.115:2.4.eng: they’re called a mendicant who is bound in ideas known by the mind. They’re trapped in Māra’s lair, fallen under Māra’s sway, and caught in Māra’s snare.

sn35.115:2.5.eng: They’re bound by Māra’s bonds, and the Wicked One can do with them what he wants.

sn35.115:3.1.pli: Santi ca kho, bhikkhave, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.115:3.1.eng: There are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.115:3.2.pli: Tañce bhikkhu nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati—
sn35.115:3.2.eng: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them,

sn35.115:3.3.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu mutto cakkhuviññeyyehi rūpehi, nāvāsagato mārassa, na mārassa vasaṃ gato, ummukkassa mārapāso.
sn35.115:3.3.eng: they’re called a mendicant who is freed from sights known by the eye. They’re not trapped in Māra’s lair, not fallen under Māra’s sway, and released from Māra’s snare.

sn35.115:3.4.pli: Mutto so mārabandhanena na yathākāmakaraṇīyo pāpimato …pe….
sn35.115:3.4.eng: They’re free from Māra’s bonds, and the Wicked One cannot do with them what he wants.

sn35.115:4.1.eng: There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.115:4.2.pli: santi, bhikkhave, manoviññeyyā dhammā, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.115:4.2.eng: ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.115:4.3.pli: Tañce bhikkhu nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati—
sn35.115:4.3.eng: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them,

sn35.115:4.4.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu mutto manoviññeyyehi dhammehi, nāvāsagato mārassa, na mārassa vasaṃ gato, ummukkassa mārapāso.
sn35.115:4.4.eng: they’re called a mendicant who is freed from ideas known by the mind. They’re not trapped in Māra’s lair, not fallen under Māra’s sway, and released from Māra’s snare.

sn35.115:4.5.pli: Mutto so mārabandhanena na yathākāmakaraṇīyo pāpimato”ti.
sn35.115:4.5.eng: They’re free from Māra’s bonds, and the Wicked One cannot do with them what he wants.”
